turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in Washington v. Chrisman.
Mr. Carpenter, I think you may begin whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
The petitioner in this matter, the state, feels there are three principal issues which the petitioner feels necessary to discuss in detail.

The first issue is whether or not exigent circumstances existed in this case that would have excused the officer of first procuring a search warrant prior to his entry into the dorm room and seizure of the marihuana seeds.

Secondly, whether or not it was proper for the law enforcement officer to accompany the arrestee, Mr. Overdahl, to the dorm room when he asked to be allowed to return to that premises to secure ID from the premises.

And thirdly, if this Court should determine that the officer acted in violation of the Fourth Amendment on the first two questions, whether or not this is an appropriate case for the Fourth Amendment exclusionary rule to be applied to.
In other words, whether or not the Court should look at the good faith of the officer in this particular case and apply a good faith exception to the exclusionary rule.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is the basic predicate of your case that if an arresting officer has probable cause to make an arrest and does so, he may keep the arrested person at least in sight if not in hand from that point on?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That is correct, Mr. Chief Justice.

Our approach is that in order to protect both the officer and protect other members of society, protect the arrestee himself and protect the evidence from being destroyed, it is nonsensical to suggest that the officer should allow the arrestee out of his immediate control and presence.

And in order to that, if he wants to be a reasonable, polite, courteous officer, wants to do what this officer tried to do, try to conduct himself in a low key, professional manner particularly on a college campus, he needed to afford the arrestee the opportunity to return to his premises, and that's basically what we're saying.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It was a return to the premises for the benefit of the arrested person.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That's correct, it was to expedite the release of the arrested person, Mr. Overdahl.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: From your point of view, from your position, the officer could have appropriately walked in the room and stayed within two or three feet of this man at all times.
Is that your position?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Wait a minute.
If a man is arrest out on the street, you could carry him across town and go into his room?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: No.
I'm not saying that.
Only if he requests to return to his premises.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But the man didn't invite him, did he?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well no, that's not really true.
The officer asked for ID and the individual indicated, Mr. Overdahl indicated that he did not have ID.
He asked the officer if he could return to the premises.
The officer indicated well, in light of your custodial status I can't let you return to the premises unless I accompany you, and Mr. Overdahl said okay.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what else could he do?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, he could have said no, that's not okay.
Take me down to the station house and book me, handcuff me.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And gone to jail.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: And gone to jail.
The officer was trying to allow him the opportunity to--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That was his choice.
It was either let the officer go with him or go to jail.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Carpenter, I gather the officer had wanted the ID, did he not, to find out his age, to use as evidence?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, that's part of the reason he wanted an ID, but you have to remember--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, he wanted it for at least that much, didn't he, for that reason?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --Well, that's true.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did he give Miranda warnings?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: No, he did not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Shouldn't he have?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: No, I don't believe so.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why, if he was going to use this as evidence, wasn't he?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, there were three reasons.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He was going to use it as evidence, wasn't he?
That's why he wanted it.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, that may have been a collateral reason.
But the principal reason he needed it, anytime you arrest an individual you have to ID that person.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, if we think he should have been given Miranda warnings and he didn't have them... you agree he didn't... wouldn't that taint everything after that?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well,--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well wouldn't it?
Under our cases?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --Not necessarily, because--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Under our cases, that he should have had them?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --Well, what would be Mr. Chrisman's standing to complain about Mr. Overdahl's violation of his Miranda rights?
That would be my answer.
Plus, the officer had a right to be out in that public hallway, regardless of whether or not he asked for his age.
The dorm room and public hallway of Orton Hall was public area; it constitutes an unprotected area, he had a right to be there.
And that's where he saw the principal observations before he went in under what we say was exigent circumstances.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Carpenter, before you leave the point, I'm still a little uncertain.
Why was the ID important?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: You have to remember... and you can look at pages 7, 9 and 10 of the Joint Appendix and read through those pages, and you will see that the officer had three violations he was aware of.
He was aware of a violation of being in possession of alcohol and in violation of a Washington statute, not being 21 years of age.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right, but he didn't need the ID to establish that because the young man had admitted he was 19.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: At the elevator before they ascended to the 11th floor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Once he admitted it, then why did he need the ID?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Because he has two other violations.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And what were they?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: One was a violation of the Washington Administrative Code which prohibits from having alcohol on the campus--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, he's on the campus; he didn't need an ID for that.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --And the third one would be he had an open container of alcohol, another criminal violation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He didn't ID for that either, did he?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, you need it... I would gently suggest that you need an ID anytime you arrest a person.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why?
If I'm arrested out on the street somewhere, do I have to have an ID?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well sooner or later, when you get booked in you are going to have to identify yourself, aren't you?
Are we going to book him in as a John Doe and hold--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He knew his name.
Do you have to have an ID in writing in order to identify yourself?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --Well, in 1978 there were approximately 16,000 students on WSU campus.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You're not suggesting that this man didn't know his own name, are you?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: No, but I would suggest that it would be rather foolhardy for an officer to take his word as to what his name was.
There are a lot of students on that campus.
We see a lot of John Smith's.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But didn't he intend to take him to the station?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, no, he was trying to allow him to be released.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does the record show that?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: I believe it does.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The man is a man that admits he's under 21, with a half a gallon of liquor.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That's right, a half a gallon of gin.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the policeman is going to let him go?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, he would issue--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes or no.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --He would issue him a uniform citation--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is it your story that he was going to turn him loose?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --Sure, he would issue him a uniform citation for a minor violation and then he would have to appear in District Court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought you said a minute ago he had a choice of taking him to the room or jail.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That's right, if you don't furnish some ID, you're going to jail.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now you say he wasn't going to take him to jail; he was going to give him a slip of paper.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: No, let me back up an explain.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I hope so.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: His choices are that if I can't resolve this with some adequate ID so I can identify you and issue you a uniform citation so you can appear in seven days in Whitman County District Court to answer the criminal charge of minor possession... it's not something that they routinely book people for--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: When he first encountered this young man, did he have any way of knowing whether the young man was, in fact, a student?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --No.
Other than that he came out of Orton Hall, he appeared to be very young, appeared to be obviously under 21.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There's a great many people of that age who might come out of that hall and have no connection with the university.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Sure.
He has no idea.

As you remember, Mr. Overdahl suggested that he be allowed to return without the officer, and I think it would be rather naive to think that a young man disappears... now maybe this young man would have come back, but I would suspect good police procedure would lead one to be a little cautious about letting a man on a campus with 16,000 disappear in the dorm.
I doubt he'd ever come back.
I mean, that's just my personal reaction.
If I was a law enforcement officer I wouldn't let him out of my sight.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, why didn't you give that answer to me when I asked you that question?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: I thought I did, but I--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you didn't give it until you got it from the Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --I apologize.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I thought you gave it to him, you gave it very clearly in response to my question.
Mr. Carpenter, when he got upstairs, did I understand you to say earlier that there were exigent circumstances which justified his entry into the room?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And had there not been is the implication that he could not have entered the room?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, I--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In the absence of exigent circumstances?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --I believe he could have entered on either one of the state's principal theories.
Either as... you have to remember, he was only at the doorway 35 to 45 seconds.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I know, but what I'm trying to get, Mr. Carpenter, do I understand your position to be that in the absence of exigent circumstances, he should not have entered the room?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: No, that is not my position.
I believe there are two ways he could have entered that room.
One, to accompany the arrestee, and I argue in the brief that if it is not a simultaneous entry, it's a contemporaneous entry.
I think it's... 35 seconds while he's standing there and then walks in.
It seems to me that the fact that he paused at the door for 30 to 45 seconds is not a great deal of constitutional significance.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And what are the exigent circumstances, assuming that there--

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Okay.

The state could argue that the exigent circumstances in this particular case are simply that if the officer had left, the tray of marihuana seeds which he observed approximately eight feet in the room from where he was standing would have I think clearly been gone when he came back.
Or it's reasonable to assume that they would have been gone.

There were two people in the room; they could have eaten them, they could have hidden them in body cavities, they could have thrown them out the window, and I won't speculate what the dispersion pattern from the 11th floor of marihuana seeds if you flip them out the window.
But I think it's reasonable, as the trial court and the Court of Appeals both concluded, that it was not reasonable for the officer to leave that room to get warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Now, incidentally, the officer had a radio, didn't he?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And it was after he entered the room that he summoned help on the radio.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why do you suppose he didn't summon held while he was at the door where he could see everything?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, he could have summoned Lieutenant Kenny--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He could see both the people, he could still see the seeds--

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --Then we'd have two officers standing at the door if he can't enter.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --What was the rationale used by the court below in this decision?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Which court?
The Washington Supreme Court or the Court of Appeals or the trial court?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I said the court below, the one immediately below is the Washington Supreme Court.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Oh, excuse me.

Their rationale was one that we never... that there were not exigent circumstances and we didn't argue them, which is clearly erroneous because the record is replete from our trial memorandum that we argued exigent circumstances.
The other was simply that New York vs. Payton and Reddy prohibited entry without a warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would it be your position that if the office was accompanying this young man down the hall and he was headed from room B, which was another few steps, but he walked by room A and he glanced into the room and saw the very same things that he saw in this case; namely, whatever it was on that stand.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Everything from that point forward proceeds the same?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And then he enters that room, saying these things are in plain view, I can enter this room and seize them because of exigent circumstances.
Is that your position?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, you have to remember in this particular case--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, just take my facts.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --Well, are the facts the same?
I mean, in this case Mr. Overdahl opened the door all the way.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the door is standing open and they are both walking by, add all of a sudden the officer sees what he saw in this case sitting on the stand.
Would that authorize his entry into the room.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: And he sees the occupant who responds to him?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, no occupant at all.
He just sees on the stand what he sees here.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, there's a lot more here.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, how about my question?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Okay, he walks by an open room and he sees the seeds.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He sees those seeds standing there... he sees what he saw in this case.
He doesn't really know they were seeds.
He had to go over to find out.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Assuming no one associated with the room or otherwise sees the officer and knows he has seen something, no, there wouldn't be.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's just like if you were walking by a house and looked through the window and saw them.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That's right, you need a warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Exactly.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: But here there is an appreciable distinction.
Here, he looks in that room, sees the contraband in plain view or open view I guess is the terminology we use--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, and then what?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --He sees a nervous reaction of Mr. Chrisman, he sees Mr. Chrisman moving the box around to the medicine cabinet, and then when he sees the officer in uniform gets all nervous and moves it back.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, if he saw the same thing through... if he was walking by on the street, he looked in the window and he saw what he saw and he saw a man in there looking nervous and was about to destroy them, could he go in?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Assuming that... are you assuming, Justice, that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I'm not assuming anything.
I just tell you what he sees.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --Well, if it's apparent the man realizes the officer has seen it, I would think so, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, does the university dormitory room necessarily occupy the same status as a single family dwelling or an apartment for purposes of the Fourth Amendment?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well I'd like to say it doesn't, but I think it probably does, in the sense that it's a premises, a living quarters, like--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's his home, isn't it, for--

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --It is his home for all practical purposes.
I would like to say it isn't, but I think, to be candid, sure it does.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Mr. Smith, so long as we're into hypotheticals, suppose we take Justice White's hypothetical, and instead of seeing some seeds in this room with which he had no concern... that is, he had no concern about the room... he saw a sawed off shotgun.
Do you mean to tell me that he shouldn't do anything about it?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: I'm not telling you that.
I think, Chief Justice, he clearly should.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I just wanted to eliminate any idea that a policeman should ignore that.
Or suppose he saw a body that appeared to be a dead body, and on reaching in and feeling the pulse, thereby violating the premises to that extent, he finds that the person is dead.
He's certainly going to do something about it, isn't he?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: One would hope.
I would think he should be suspended or fired if he didn't do something.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: It's correct police procedure.
I don't think the Fourth Amendment requires officers to disregard things.
And all the state's position is on the first issue in this case is that there were, in fact, exigent circumstances.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If they see the evidence of an unlawful, criminal act, they must do something, whatever that something is.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, with the additional that when the occupant or occupants of the premises appreciate the officer's... the word is out, so to speak, the know the thing is up, if the officer leaves I just don't think it's reasonable to expect under the Fourth Amendment that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, your premise for this position is that he knew what he saw.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --Well, the Court of Appeals and the trial court believed that.
They believe there was a reasonable basis--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you think that he did know exactly what he saw.
He didn't have to go over and find out what was there.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --No, no, I think--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He may have suspected it, but did he really know.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --The respondent tries to argue, Mr. Justice, that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Carpenter, at that point let me ask how far did you say, again, he was?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --Okay, he's 8 to 10 feed from the doorjamb to the black tray with the marihuana seeds and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Which is less than the distance between you and this bench.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --That's right.
And this is an experienced officer, trained and experienced in controlled substances.
There's no question in my mind from reading the record that the officer knew and believed that he had probable cause that it was marihuana.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Carpenter, my understanding is that this respondent was under arrest at the time.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The Supreme Court of Washington so held.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And you've been talking now for quite a while, or responding to some questions about situations where officers looking through windows and standing at doorways, as to what rights they may have.

I would think you would argue this case as to the rights of an officer where he has made a lawful arrest to stay with the party arrested and to observe anything that he could observe in those circumstances.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: I think that's correct, Justice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Doesn't the fact that this involved a lawful arrest and a search incident to arrest distinguish this case from much of what we've been talking about?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: I think that's correct, and that's the second principal issue in this case.
I think this case can be decided either on the first issue or the second issue.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Carpenter, I'm confused now.
I have heard you talk about exigent circumstances, I have heard you talk about search incident to a lawful arrest, and I think I've heard you talk about plain view.
What is it you're really relying on?
Are you relying on the fact, as you allege it to be, that the officer was in a place where he had a right to be and he saw items, contraband, in plain view?
Or are you relying on exigent circumstances, or search lawful... incident to a lawful arrest, or all three or what?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Yes, Justice O'Connor, unfortunately, the last court before this Court, the Washington Supreme Court... and not to criticize that court, but I think it improperly labeled where the officer was as a nicety, and they said we're not going to decide that issue.
I think it's pretty important.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what are you relying on?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Our position is... and I suppose the prosecutor wants the best of both worlds... I think we can rely on both the exigent circumstances; one, what he saw in open view while he was standing out in a public place and the occupant's reaction to him; and two, that he had a right, regardless of that, to accompany the arrestee into the premises to start with.

And so, pursuant to the arrest status, for his protection, the protection of the public, the protection of the evidence, protection of veracity, so I think I'm arguing that we have the best of both worlds.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And he sees something in plain view?
I'm still confused what the thrust of your argument is.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, I guess the first argument is in open view, he sees it, it's in a public place, that's exigent circumstances.
Now even setting that aside, I think that... the state would like to believe that answers the issue.

But setting that aside and forgetting about exigent circumstances for a moment, we also would argue that if he was, in fact, in the room, or when in the room to accompany the arrestee, once he got in the room, it's in plain view, clearly he had a right to go into the room, attendant to the arrest status of Mr. Overdahl, and that it comes under, you know, proper police procedure to accompany Mr. Overdahl in that room, and what he sees there is in plain view.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, unlike Justice O'Connor, who has recently joined our Court, do you think that any of the courts in the country or any prosecutor or any defense lawyer can be faulted for being somewhat confused about the state of Fourth Amendment law?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, I've been practicing law for ten years, and the cops always call me up at 3:00 in the morning and want me to give them a precise answer to the Fourth Amendment, and I can't do it.

I think it's so enamored with constitutional subtleties and what I like to call the crafting of legal technicians that we've totally confused not only the lawyers and the judges, but the police officers who are supposed to be constitutional lawyers out in the street and making a 15-second decision to decide what the U.S. Constitution means.
All I'm saying in this case is that the conduct was reasonable.
The officer did what was reasonable under the status of the law clearly in 1978, in any event.
That was before Mincey vs. Arizona and before Payton.
It's a very confusing area.
This case is important maybe to clarify what... first of all, what is an exigent circumstance.
I, for the life of me, could not find a real good U.S. Supreme Court case that clearly found an exigent; I found a lot that said it wasn't and said what you should be looking for.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Carpenter, on the question of exigent circumstances, the Chief Justice gave you examples of seeing a gun or a dead body or something like that.
Is it your view that the character of the crime, the degree of violence associated and so forth has anything to do with the exigent circumstances inquiry?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: No, I don't--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You would treat this case involving--

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --I don't prescribe to the theory that it has to be a serious crime--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --involving the use of marihuana as equally as serious as a murder or anything else.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --And particularly when we get into the second issue in this case about arrest, I just don't think it's reasonable to say a officer can only take reasonable precautions to protect himself when it's a serious offense.
It's not uncommon for officers to be shot on a minor traffic stop.
All kinds of minor things.

As the amicus points out in their brief, arrest status sort of brings out the worst in some people, and in the most low key looking situation, an officer may find himself in a very precarious position.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I guess it's not uncommon to find marihuana in college dorms, either.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Oh, no, very common.
It's a way of life at WSU, I believe.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Carpenter, are you familiar with a case we decided last June, I think the title of it was New York against Belton?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Yes, I am.
And I think you decided Robbins or something like that the same day.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

But the Belton case, as I recall, involved an officer who stopped an automobile and made a lawful arrest and the Court held that the officer was entitled, without a warrant, to search anything in the driver's compartment of the car... passenger compartment of the car.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That's right.
And I believe that case made--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Anything that he could find there.
Now, the plain view doctrine certainly applies... I've always understood it... when an officer makes a lawful arrest.
Why do you avoid relying primarily on that issue?
Am I overlooking something?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --I excuse myself.
I don't mean to... I guess like I said, I'm trying to have the best of both worlds.
I think this case can be decided on both issues.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You're trying to argue three cases at one time.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, I suppose if you can find three ways to hang your hat on it, I... you know, in Washington state, the prosecutor loses 80 % of the time on all issues before the Washington Supreme Court in the last two or three years, so we try to cover the issues.
We try to find some way to sustain our--
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I guess you can hang your hat on which ever one you want.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: I'd like to have my convictions sustained.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, there is a difference between the Belton case and this.
There we had the mobility of an automobile, which had a special character.
Here you have an immobile place.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: But the language I find particular significant maybe to this case and Belton and maybe the Robinson and Gustafson cases, are the Court's observations that arrested people are very unpredictable.
You know, an officer has to do enough to protect himself.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, this officer might reasonably be reprimanded for not having gone in and followed him around to be sure he wasn't going to come out to the door with a sawed off shotgun in his hand.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: I would not have done what this officer did.
I would have gone in immediately.
Because if you look at the record you will see that the young man gets into a drawer or a closet or something.
Who knows there's not a pistol or something in there?
I just think that he should have done a little more to protect himself than he did, but like I said, they're trying to act low key on the campus.
They don't want to get a lot of bad publicity.
That's pretty clear from the Joint Appendix.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Counsel, does the record show when this man was given his Miranda warning?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Okay, he was first given his Miranda warnings after the officer seized the tray of marihuana.

At that point, he gave both the occupants their Miranda warnings, and at that juncture asked if there was anything else in the room, and at that point Mr. Chrisman went ahead and volunteered the little box the officer had seen him carrying around.
It had $112 and some marihuana in it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So he wasn't given Miranda warnings--

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Not prior to the entry.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --until he was arrested for the marihuana.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He wasn't given Miranda warnings about the liquor.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And yet, the purpose of the ID was for the liquor.

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, the purpose of the ID, the state would like to say is that you have to ID anybody that you arrest.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Where did you get that idea that you have to get an ID everytime you arrest a man?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, I believe it's correct police procedure.
You have to ultimately book them under a name, and you have to verify them, and when you have... we do have a problem with people even appearing in our district court under phony names.
I prosecuted a couple young men a couple months ago on just that.
They went clear through the conviction stage using a phony name.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there a requirement that you identify yourself?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, I think it's reasonable for an officer to ask them; I don't know if you can force somebody to identify himself, but I think it's reasonable police procedure--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is it reasonable to take a man back to his home after you arrest him?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --If he wishes to go, whether it's for a coat or drugs or ID, you know, prescription medicine, why ever he wants to go back.
I think it's the humane thing to do.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you don't have a right to go there, do you?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Well, I think he doesn't have a right to go home, either, unless he allows you to accompany him.
And if he says okay, I want to go back--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you don't have a right to accompany him unless--

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: --That's right, that's our argument.
It seems that if he's going to go back, then he has to have a modified right there.
It's not reasonable to let him go back by himself.
At least, that's the state's position.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Mr. Carpenter, can we be certain the Washington court based its decision on the Fourth Amendment to the federal Constitution rather than on the Washington constitutional provision?

turn.speaker: ronald_r_carpenter
turn.label: Mr. Ronald R. Carpenter
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, that's one issue the respondent argues in their brief, and, of course, we argue that there's absolutely no discussion of Article I, Section 7 in the Washington state constitution in our decision.
They talk about the Fourth Amendment and they talk about Payton and Rettig, and it seems to me clear that that's what they decided the case on.
Now, looking at the Simpson case cited by the respondent, we argue that's really just a limited case on standing in response to this Court's case Racus.

Looking at, I think it's State vs. Smith, it's in my reply brief, the Court clearly a couple years ago in Washington said that the two sections, Article I, Section 7 of the Washington constitution and the Fourth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution should be substantially interpreted the same.
And so, it's the state's position that they should be, and that's what was done.
I think it's mere speculation on respondent's part that it could have been.
Whether it could or couldn't, it doesn't appear that they ever talked about the Washington state constitution in this case.
If there are no further questions, I would like to reserve the remainder of my time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Carpenter.
Mr. Patrick?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

If this case is to be decided on federal constitutional grounds, I would submit to the Court that a fundamental precept of the Constitution, that possibly this case should be considered in conjunction with or determined, is a portion of the Constitution which is seldom cited and neither counsel has cited, frankly, but seldom cited because it's part of the Preamble, and that part of the Preamble says
"to secure the blessings of our liberty to ourselves and our posterity. "

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the Preamble has never been considered part of the Constitution for adjudication purposes, has it?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: No, Your Honor, no, it has not.
But I think that the Fourth Amendment was adopted in part to give rise or life to that portion of the Preamble; that is,
"to secure the blessing of liberty. "
and part of the blessing of liberty would be the right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, are you suggesting that, Mr. Patrick, to negate the thought that the policeman, once having placed this man under arrest, had a right, if not a duty, to keep him within arm's length at all times until he had completed all the formalities?
Any question about that in your mind?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I have to say to Your Honor that it is my judgment that the police officer probably had, as long as he had placed the individual under arrest, that the police officer could be with him as he went wherever this individual went.
I do not believe, however, that the police officer had the right to accompany this... to have this individual go to his room to secure the identification.
I also would submit to the Court that the police officer did not have the right to accompany him specifically into the room--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Whose idea was it to go to the room?
The officer's or the arrested persons's?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --I believe it was, in essence, the officer because the officer left the individual no choice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Isn't it ambiguous from the Supreme Court of Washington where it says at rage 35 of the Petition for Certiorari,
"The officer noticed the bottle of gin and suspected that Overdahl was under the age of 21. "
"He stopped Overdahl and requested his identification. "
"Overdahl stated that he would have to go upstairs to his room to get the identification. "
"Officer Daugherty required that he would have to accompany him to his room. "
It's kind of hard to say from that description, isn't it, who... whether there was insistence on one party or the other?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Not from our standpoint, Your Honor.
I submit that the insistence was for ID, and the officer wanted that ID.
Not having advised Mr. Overdahl of his Miranda rights, he did not have the right to insist on ID.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Was the arrest lawful, do you concede, even though he had no Miranda rights?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Your Honor, I'll be frank with you in this.
I have vacillated back and forth in my own mind on it.
The officer--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It makes a difference, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --The officer... I believe at that point, at that point.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What point is that?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: The point where the police officer said, I will have to go with you to the room--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: At the elevator?
Was that near the elevator or something?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --Yes.
He was in the lobby.
He motioned Mr. Overdahl over and he said, I'll have to see some ID for that gin, or words to that effect.
Mr. Overdahl then I said I don't have it with me, I'll have to go up to my room and get it.
If you'll wait for me, I'll bring it back.
And the officer said no, under these circumstances I will have to go with you.
And later on during cross examination--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, at what point was he arrested?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --I believe at that point.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That was a lawful arrest, even though there were no Miranda warnings?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: No, I do not believe at that point that the arrest was lawful, Your Honor, because the police officer at that point knew that he could not get past basically a motion to dismiss at the trial if all he came before the judge was... if all he brought before the judge... was I've arrested this individual and this individual looks like he's under 21, to me.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Wasn't he charged for just having liquor on the campus?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Wasn't one of the charges just being in possession of liquor on the campus?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: That was in violation of a Washington Administrative Code, Your Honor, but the police officer indicated that he would not have arrested that individual, in essence, for that; there would be no criminal actions.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What the officer's subjective intent was I don't know is controlling.
He had, in fact, committed a violation of that regulation.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Of the Washington Administrative Code apparently, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And was that not a violation for which he could have been issued a citation of some kind?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: He could have... frankly, I'm not really sure that he could be issued a citation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I'm not really sure that he could be issued a citation as such.
He would certainly go to... it would go to the office of the dean of students, and there would have been initiated... I do not believe there would have been initiated any criminal sanctions for that.
They would have gone to the dean of students and he may have been disciplined through whatever university disciplinary procedures.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: On page 35, the Supreme Court of Washington again says, as they were waiting for the elevator, the officer asked Overdahl how old he was.
Overdahl responded that he was 19.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Yes.
At that point I believe he now had the probable cause to arrest.
But I believe that the custody of Mr. Overdahl--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about Miranda warnings?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --I believe the custody of Mr. Overdahl--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No.
What about when he conceded, I am 19.
Was he entitled to Miranda warnings if--

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, he was entitled to the Miranda warnings.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Well, do you make any point of the fact he didn't get them?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Even though he conceded he was 19, without the Miranda warnings you suggest, or you argue, that the arrest was still unlawful?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I am arguing that when the officer said, I will accompany you to the room, that he now had put... he had so restricted Mr. Overdahl's freedom of movement that he was now under arrest.
And at that time he had a duty to advise Mr. Overdahl of his rights under Miranda.
I believe it happens that that arrest may--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I'm sorry, but how can the respondent take advantage of the failure to give Miranda warnings to his roommate?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --Because it is the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The failure to give Miranda warnings doesn't vitiate the arrest, does it?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --But that's what led directly to... as indicated in our brief, that's what led directly to the opening of the door, which was a giving up of the right of privacy to the room.
And under... then that brings into play Bumper and, I believe, Crewes that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I simply don't follow this argument.
If the arrest is valid, it doesn't matter whether he gave Miranda warnings or not, does it?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --I believe that... yes, Your Honor, I believe it does because he wanted to get that ID for proof of an element of the offense.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you would infer that; your opponent infers something different on that.
But regardless of his motive, if he made a valid arrest, as Justice Powell has suggested, what difference does it make whether... I just don't follow your argument.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: The reason that it becomes important, Your Honor, is that the sole reason for going to that room was for identification.
The identification would have--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Done two things.
He could have ticketed him without taking him to the station, and he would have had written as well as oral proof of age.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Granted all that, still, now what's your argument?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I believe that at that point, not having advised him of his rights to Miranda, he did not have a right to, in essence, insist that the individual goes to his room, or even, there was no need for the individual to go to his room.
And I believe that the police officer then took advantage of the situation to get the individual to his room.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I still don't follow.
The failure to give Miranda warnings makes subsequent statements inadmissible in evidence.
Is there any doctrine that says that failure to give Miranda warnings makes it wrong for a police officer to take a person in custody to his room?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, when going to the room is to obtain that evidence.
I believe that having put the individual under arrest, having failed to advise the individual of the rights under Miranda--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And so the evidence is inadmissible.
Even though it's not the person who was ultimately charged.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --Yes, the concept, from my view anyway, Your Honor, the concept is that the police officer could not have stood outside the door and beaten Mr. Overdahl to a pulp and said open the door, and Mr. Overdahl finally opens the door.
I believe that Mr. Chrisman could argue and just as effectively would have standing to assert the manner in which that door was opened.
Because his privacy to the room was invaded because of a violation of his co tenant's right to privacy.
I believe that's in essence what Bumper ruled when the mother allowed the police officer to come in.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But what about this expression that was raised by the Chief Justice a little while back.
Under all the circumstances you say he comes in the room and finds a loaded, double barreled, sawed off shotgun.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I believe, Your Honor, at that juncture there is, in fact, I believe, a difference in the quality of the item; not... at that point the officer is at least is interested in his personal safety and the personal safety of the people around as he would be evidence.
And I believe that the sawed off shotgun could just as easily be confiscated under exigent circumstances--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But he wouldn't have seen if, to quote you, he hadn't violated the roommate's rights.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --That is correct, that assumes that he is properly at the door.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, doesn't that cut back on your point a little bit?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's not absolute, is it?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: No, it is not, Your Honor.
I believe he would have a better case to go in to seize it for his own protection.
But still and all, it was there because of a violation of constitutional rights.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, suppose it was poison there.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Poison, which can kill just as easily as a shotgun.
And which can also be poured down the toilet and disposed of.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: In this case, there was no toilet in the room, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Was there a window in the room?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: There was a window in the room.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It could be thrown out of the window.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Yes, if they wanted to break the window.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, they could raise the window; they weren't crippled, were they?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I believe at that point, once the window was raised--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I just don't understand how you can bootstrap these arguments.
Even if you admit that you... if the prosecutor here admits that he had no right to follow the man but he did follow him, that he should have given him Miranda warnings but he didn't.
I don't see how that helps your client.
That's my problem.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --Your Honor,--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Even if I think it helps the other guy, I don't think it helps your client.
Now, does that make it clear?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, but as I indicated, I believe that the police officer, as far as my client, Mr. Chrisman, is concerned, if the police officer secured the opening of the door by beating up on Mr. Overdahl until he finally, through an act of submission, opened the door,--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Which is not here.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --No, but the principle I think is going to be the same.
A violation of a constitutional right should give the co tenant the right to object to the manner in which the privacy was given up.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You mean the right... looking into an open door is the same as breaking the door down.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: For constitutional--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There's a little bit of difference.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, if you--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Patrick, I wonder if even that follows.
Supposing he lawfully arrested him downstairs, and on the way up he beated him up in the elevator and violated his constitutional rights.
And then said, I still am going to follow you into the room.
If he has a right to follow him into the room, the fact that he beat him up in the elevator wouldn't destroy that right, would it?
I mean, there would be remedies for what he did, but I'm not sure one of the remedies is that he has to turn him loose.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --I don't believe he has to turn him loose, Your Honor, but I'm not sure that he can--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, if he can keep him under arrest and if you can stay with your arrestee and go into a room, it doesn't seem to me that if you did something else that's very wrong on the way in has changed the legal posture at all.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --I think that if you fail... if you violate the individual's rights and in violating those rights of that individual, the constitutional rights of that individual--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Beat him up in the elevator.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --Right, Your Honor.
If that goes to the validity of the consent to go to the room--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Under the theory, at least the one Justice Powell has been suggesting, he didn't need consent.
He had the man under arrest, and the man goes in the room, he has a right to follow him in.
And I'm just suggesting that he doesn't lose that right because he did something terrible in the elevator; if he has the right.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --You may be right, Your Honor, unless it goes to the consent of the individual to go to the room, and then I have to go back to the proposition--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But see, it you have the arrest situation, then you don't need the consent.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --Except that, Your Honor, just simply because an individual is under arrest doesn't mean that the police officer has to take him to the room.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I see what you're saying.
One more hypothetical.
He does everything you say to one of the men, and as he gets to the door, the wind blows the door open and he sees all of that.
He can't seize it.
Do you want to bet?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Where the wind has blown the door open?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.
Just as he got there.
Fortuitous wind.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I think that's a fortuitous event all right, Your Honor, but constitutionally... well again, we go back to the proposition... I have to go back to the proposition that the police officer was there because, under our theory of the case, he had not adequately advised the individual of his rights under Miranda, and therefore--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well the police officer employed by the university sure had a right to be standing in that hallway.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --He had a right to be in the hallway, that's true.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the door blew open, on my hypothetical.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I think, Your Honor, that when the doorway was blown open, it has not now come open by an event which one of the defendants was in control of.
None of the parties was in control of.
It's a little bit like the Chief Justice's question I think where the police officer is bringing Mr. Overdahl down the hall and the police officer sees some marihuana in another room.
And in that case, I would say he could go in.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But the Chief Justice says you might have to get a warrant, but you said he doesn't even have to get one.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: No, no, I'm sorry, Your Honor, I don't mean to infer that he didn't have to get a warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought that you just said that that would be a different case and the officer could do it.
But failure to give Miranda warnings does not vitiate an otherwise lawful arrest, does it?
It just means that a motion to suppress may be granted, but we'll suppress items that were surrendered by the victim under the... because of the failure to advise him of his rights.
It doesn't mean that the state can't prove its case by other evidence.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: That's my understanding, Your Honor, that is correct.
I do not believe that the state can prove its case by evidence that would arise from the individual.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that's... but this isn't the same individual.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: But it is an individual who is in the same position, as I indicated earlier... at least I would submit to the Court that when the individual has... when a co tenant has given up the privacy of the premises because of a violation of that co tenant's rights, the non consenting co tenant should, I submit, stand in the same shoes, because it is the protection of the privacy of the premises that I believe is at stake.

And this Court has on several occasions indicated that it will certainly assert and recognize the rights of the people who are... who have possessory interest in the property, although that is not necessarily the key.

But again I believe that Bumper handles the standing question in which the mother, I believe it was, who owned the premises gave... acceded to the request of the police officers to come in under the proposition that they had a search warrant.
And it was the defendant then who was given standing to assert that the entry was invalid because it was under the mistaken hypothesis that the police officer did have a search warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Tell me, Mr. Patrick, assuming there is no infirmity whatever in the arrest of Overdahl and they went up to the room, as they did, might not... or do you think the officer could accompany Overdahl into the room?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Under the facts of this case, Your Honor--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, I suggested them.
If there is no infirmity whatever in the arrest of Overdahl.
You go up to the room because Overdahl has said, I want to get the ID for you.
Could not the officer accompany him into the room?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --The Washington Supreme Court said no.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What do you think?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Ah--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And why not, if you're going to answer he couldn't?
I would suppose the officer would be able to be sure that he wasn't going to be attacked or assaulted.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --That's why I said I didn't think so under the facts of this case.
I can understand why a police officer would want to be in a position where he could protect himself from an attack or an assault.
The problem is, in this case, a police officer's actions did not give any indication that he had any concern about that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Because he stood in the doorway instead of entering, is that it?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: He stood in the doorway, he had not frisked the individual before he got there, at least the record doesn't disclose that he did.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Let's suppose, however, that he had entered.
Would there be anything wrongful about that entry?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: If he had gone into the room?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.
If he had gone in with Overdahl.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Under our Supreme Court's decision, which we submit could be supported under the Washington constitution, and under State vs. Seiss, a New Jersey decision we cited in our brief, the theory is that there are some types of arrests which are so insignificant that it is not valid for the police officer to accompany the individual into the room.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Incidentally, there is no suggestion that the Washington Supreme Court decided this case under the Washington constitution, is there?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: The Washington Supreme Court cited State vs. Daugherty, which is a Washington case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, do you think they rested this on the state constitution rather than the federal?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I think that they could have and I'm not 100 % sure.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, did they?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I'm not really sure, frankly, whether they did or did not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If they did, we would have no jurisdiction over this case, obviously.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, do you suggest they did?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Yes, I'm suggesting that this Court... if this Court believes that the search could be upheld under federal constitutional grounds, I believe that the case should be remanded back to the State Supreme Court to see if the State Supreme Court decided the case under the state constitution.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why did the State Supreme Court cite all the federal constitutional cases if it was deciding it under the Washington constitution?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I believe, Your Honor, that the concept that the states can interpret their own constitution and can grant additional rights over and above those granted to the federal Constitution frankly is of relatively recent origin, and I don't think it's been thoroughly thought out, frankly.
I believe in Mr. Justice Brennan's Law Review article he propounded that proposition.

And I think that frankly, part of the reason would be, although it's up to the state supreme court to say for themselves, but I would think that part of the reason is that the state supreme courts have grown so accustomed to examining questions in light of what they think the United States Supreme Court is going to rule, that they are very used to taking precedent from the U.S. Supreme Court.

And I believe, however, that in the future, as this theory is... we all have more experience with this theory, it would not surprise me to see state supreme court decisions resting their decision on their state constitutional grounds where it is their view that additional rights are granted under their respective constitutions.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But we're reviewing a judgment here that's not in the future but was rendered in the past.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
But one of the authorities cited by the state supreme court was, as I say, the State vs. Daugherty.
Now, State vs. Daugherty itself cited some federal cases and some state cases, and I did review some of those state cases and again, those cases cited are also state and federal cases.

I believe that the state supreme court could have decided this case under the state constitution, and as I indicated earlier, if this Court feels that the state constitution... or rather, that the federal Constitution was not violated by the search, then I would request the Court, again, to remand it back to the state supreme court for a determination as to whether or not the search could be sustained under the state constitution.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Isn't the test whether it did decide it rather than whether it could have decided it, under Privda and Minnesota vs. National Tea and those cases?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Your Honor, I think that may well be, but I think that where the supreme court, or where the case... if the case were to be reversed and go back to the trial court, I would think that if the trial court then were to sentence the individual and impose a sentence, that again, we would probably be faced with trying to go back up to the state supreme court and give the state supreme court an opportunity to rule on the constitutionality of... under the state constitution.
And I believe it would avoid a lot of circular action if it were simply to go back to the state supreme court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Of course, this business of deciding cases on state constitutional principles rather than federal is nothing new.
We've been doing it up here for a long time.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that is true.

But I think in the... I believe certainly in recent history under the state court... under the constitutional principles, the state supreme courts have... particularly after Mann... have become accustomed to following the precedent of the U.S. Supreme Court, and feel... I believe for a time felt pretty much locked in by the precedents set by this Court.

And the state supreme court then should be allowed, I submit, to decide this case on state constitutional principles, if the Court determines that this case should not be decided as incorrect under federal constitutional principles.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Patrick, on that point, did you tell us... I want to be sure I understood what you were saying... that there is a state constitutional doctrine that more or less classifies certain offenses as very petty offenses and that if this offense is in that category, that as a matter of state law, the entry into the room might not have been justified by the fact that the man was under arrest.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: That's my... the state supreme court said that this type... an arrest for this type of offense did not justify the police officer accompanying the individual into the room.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's in the... is that the Daugherty case the courts have found that--

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: No, that's my understanding of the Chrisman case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Of the holding in this case, I see, all right.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: Yes.

The Simpson case, which we cited for the proposition that the state court can interpret its own constitution and indeed has interpreted in some instances the state constitution to give the additional rights than those given under the federal Constitution, we submit was not simply standing, because standing is not a constitutional interpretation, as I see it.
So I believe the state constitution could vindicate the holding of the state court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Patrick, may I review with you just a moment to be clear, are you now willing to concede that Mr. Overdahl had been lawfully arrested before the officer accompanied him to his room?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: I believe that when... yes, Your Honor, when the police officer found out that he was under the age of 19, I believe that at that point--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The answer is yes?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And do you concede that the officer was lawfully at the doorway of the room with Mr. Overdahl?

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
turn.text: No, Your Honor, because I do not believe that the police officer had given Mr. Overdahl his Miranda rights, and therefore, did not have the right to accompany him to get evidence against Mr. Overdahl.
And that if anything--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you would concede there are circumstances which would justify an officer in accompanying the person arrested to his dwelling, into the dwelling.

turn.speaker: robert_f_patrick
turn.label: Mr. Robert F. Patrick
